intro: Spermacoce lagunensis, commonly known as the marsh spurge, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its erect, herbaceous stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in cymes, and it is often found in wetlands and disturbed soils. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release tiny, wind-dispersed seeds. Spermacoce lagunensis is known for its adaptability to moist environments and its role in ecological succession.
